[File: light/odr.go] [Struct: CodeRequest] [Empty code handling] If Data is empty (length 0), does this correctly represent the empty code hash, or can this cause inconsistencies with accounts that should have no code? (Low)

[File: light/odr.go] [Struct: TrieRequest] [Nil proof handling] If Proof is nil when StoreResult() is called, does this cause a nil pointer dereference panic crashing the node? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: peerWrapper] [Embedding conflicts] Does the embedded clientPeer in peerWrapper have methods that conflict with NodeStateMachine expectations, causing method resolution ambiguity? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Function: newServerSetup()] [Allocation failure] If memory allocation for nodestate.Setup fails, does newServerSetup() handle this gracefully or return a partially initialized serverSetup that causes crashes later? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: serverSetup] [Flag dependency] Must priorityFlag be set before balanceField can be assigned, or vice versa, and can violating this order create inconsistent client states? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Function: newServerSetup()] [Initialization order] Does the order of field initialization (clientField, balanceField, capacityField, queueField) matter for state machine operations, and can reordering cause dependencies to break? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: peerWrapper] [Wrapper bypass] Can the NodeStateMachine type system be exploited to unwrap or bypass the peerWrapper, accessing the raw clientPeer and manipulating it without proper validation? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: serverSetup] [Active/Inactive bypass] Can the activeFlag be set without satisfying minimum capacity requirements, or can the inactiveFlag be cleared without going through proper activation logic, bypassing capacity limits? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: serverSetup] [Update flag abuse] Can a malicious client trigger the updateFlag repeatedly without actual priority changes, causing excessive priority recalculations and callback storms that DoS the server? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: serverSetup] [Queue manipulation] Can the queueField containing ppNodeInfo be tampered with to manipulate the client's position in the priority queue, granting unfair capacity allocation? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: serverSetup] [Capacity bypass] Can the capacityField be set directly without going through the priority pool's capacity allocation logic, allowing clients to claim unlimited capacity and DoS the server? (Critical)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: serverSetup] [Priority manipulation] Can the priorityFlag be set manually without updating the balanceField, creating a false priority status that grants capacity to clients with zero or negative balance? (Critical)

[File: les/vflux/server/status.go] [Struct: serverSetup] [Balance corruption] Can the balanceField be modified directly without going through the balance tracker, bypassing balance validation and allowing negative balances or balance overflow attacks? (Critical)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Non-atomic batch processing] Requests in a batch are processed sequentially at lines 92-96. If processing is interrupted, are partial results returned? Could this violate atomicity expectations? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Results ordering] The results slice at line 91 is populated in request order. If backend.Handle() implementations have side effects, could ordering issues cause state inconsistencies? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Round-trip data corruption] During the decode-process-encode cycle (lines 106-113), could data be corrupted if RLP encoding is not bijective with decoding? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Delay accumulation] With delayPerRequest set, could an attacker queue many requests to accumulate large delays, effectively time-locking server resources? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Decode CPU exhaustion] Could specially crafted RLP data at line 106 trigger expensive decode operations, exhausting CPU resources? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Lock contention DoS] By sending many concurrent requests, could an attacker cause severe lock contention at line 90, degrading service for all users? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Algorithmic complexity DoS] If backend.Handle() implementations have O(n^2) or worse complexity, could attackers craft requests that trigger worst-case performance? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Register()] [Registration timing attacks] Could an attacker measure service registration timing to infer internal state or service implementation details? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Service enumeration] By probing different service IDs in requests, could an attacker enumerate all registered services and their characteristics? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Request batching abuse] Can an attacker send batches of 16 requests (MaxRequestLength) where each request targets expensive backend operations to maximize DoS impact per batch? (High)
[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Empty encoded request] If req is an empty byte slice, could RLP decoding produce unexpected results or errors? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Register()] [Empty service ID] If srv.id is an empty string, it would pass the ':' check at line 64. Could empty service IDs cause issues when looking up services in Serve()? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Zero-length results] If all backends return nil or empty byte slices, the results slice will be full of nils. Is this distinguishable from an error condition? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [MaxRequestLength boundary] The check at line 80 uses '>' to compare with MaxRequestLength. Is the boundary condition correct? Could exactly MaxRequestLength requests be valid? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Stop()] [Limiter cleanup coordination] Stop() calls limiter.Stop() at line 119, but doesn't wait for in-flight Serve() calls to complete. Could this cause use-after-free or race conditions? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Limiter cost parameter always 0] The value parameter at line 84 is always 0, ignoring economic incentives. Could this enable free unlimited requests? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [No timeout on limiter wait] The function blocks indefinitely at line 84 waiting for the limiter channel. Could a stuck limiter cause the entire server to hang? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Limiter.Add() return value assumptions] At line 84, the code assumes limiter.Add() returns a channel. What if the limiter implementation changes or returns unexpected values? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: NewServer()] [Services map not pre-allocated] The services map at line 57 is created without initial capacity. For servers expecting many service registrations, could this cause frequent reallocations and performance issues? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: NewServer()] [No validation of delayPerRequest] The delayPerRequest parameter is not validated in NewServer(). Could extremely large or negative values cause issues? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: NewServer()] [Limiter capacity hardcoded] The limiter is created with a hardcoded capacity of 1000 at line 55. Should this be configurable? Could incorrect values cause either DoS vulnerability or service degradation? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Backend return value validation] The bytes returned from backend.Handle() at line 94 are not validated. Could backends return malformed data that causes issues during RLP encoding? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Backend state corruption] If a backend.Handle() implementation maintains state and expects sequential calls per node ID, could interleaved requests from different nodes cause state corruption? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Backend Handle() thread safety] The comment at line 43 says Handle() is 'never called concurrently', but is this guarantee actually enforced? Could bugs in the limiter break this assumption? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Request replay attacks] There's no nonce or timestamp validation in requests. Could an attacker capture and replay valid requests to waste server resources? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Amplification attack vector] The function decodes a potentially small RLP request and may return a large encoded response. Could this be exploited for bandwidth amplification DDoS attacks? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [No authentication on requests] There's no cryptographic authentication of requests beyond the enode.ID parameter. Could an attacker forge requests from arbitrary node IDs? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [UDP address spoofing] At line 109, the address is extracted from net.UDPAddr. Could an attacker spoof UDP source addresses to bypass rate limiting by appearing as multiple sources? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: NewServer()] [Negative delay parameter] If NewServer() is called with a negative delayPerRequest, could this cause unexpected behavior in time.Sleep() at line 98? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Delay calculation precision] The delay calculation at line 98 uses time.Duration multiplication. Could very small delayPerRequest values result in zero delay due to truncation? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Sleep while holding resources] At line 98, time.Sleep is called after releasing the lock but before closing the channel. Could this delay prevent the limiter from processing other requests efficiently? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Encode error ignored] The error from rlp.EncodeToBytes at line 113 is explicitly ignored with '_'. Could encoding failures result in silent data corruption? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Error propagation from Handle()] The Handle() method returns []byte with no error return. If processing fails, how does the backend signal errors? Could nil returns be misinterpreted as success? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Decode error not logged] When RLP decoding fails at line 106, the function silently returns nil without logging. Could this hide attacks or bugs making debugging difficult? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Panic in Handle() not recovered] If service.backend.Handle() panics at line 94, there's no recover() to catch it. Could a malicious or buggy backend implementation crash the entire server? (Critical)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Register()] [Service metadata consistency] The serviceEntry stores id and desc, but these are not used in Serve(). Could inconsistencies between registered metadata and actual service behavior cause issues? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Inconsistent nil handling] ServeEncoded() returns nil on decode error (line 107) and when Serve() returns nil (line 111), but also returns nil from EncodeToBytes error (line 113). Can clients distinguish between different failure modes? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Partial results on error] If a backend.Handle() call panics or an error occurs mid-loop at line 92-96, results could be partially populated. Should this return partial results or nil? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Register()] [Lock not held during validation] The service ID validation at line 64 occurs before acquiring the lock. Could this create a race window where two threads both pass validation and then both acquire the lock to register? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Lock scope too broad] The lock is held from line 90 to 97, covering the entire loop that calls external Handle() functions. Could this cause unnecessary contention and performance degradation? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Stop()] [Missing lock in Stop()] The Stop() function at line 118 only calls s.limiter.Stop() without acquiring s.lock. Could concurrent Register() or Serve() calls cause race conditions during shutdown? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Node ID spoofing] The enode.ID is passed as a parameter without cryptographic verification. Could an attacker spoof node IDs to bypass rate limiting or gain unfair service priority? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Address validation] The address string parameter is passed without validation. Could extremely long addresses or addresses with special characters cause issues in downstream processing or logging? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Request params validation] The req.Params bytes at line 94 are passed directly to backend.Handle() without validation. Could malformed params cause panics or exploits in backend implementations? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Unregistered service requests] At line 93, if req.Service doesn't match any registered service, no result is added to results[i], leaving it as nil. Could this cause client-side panics or misinterpretation of results? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Empty request handling] At line 80, if reqLen is 0, the function returns nil. Is this the correct behavior, or should it return an empty response? Could this break client logic expecting a response? (Low)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: NewServer()] [Services map unbounded growth] The services map at line 57 is initialized without size limits. Combined with unlimited Register() calls, could this lead to unbounded memory growth? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Sleep-based DoS amplification] At line 98, the server sleeps for delayPerRequest * reqLen. Can an attacker send maximum-length batches to tie up server resources for extended periods? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Unbounded Handle() execution] The service.backend.Handle() call at line 94 has no timeout or resource limits. Could a malicious backend implementation run forever or consume excessive CPU, causing DoS? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Results slice allocation] At line 91, results is allocated with len(requests) capacity. Can an attacker send requests with MaxRequestLength to allocate large slices repeatedly, exhausting memory? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Blocked channel receive] The channel received at line 84 is meant to be closed by this function at line 99, but what if the limiter's processLoop is stuck or deadlocked? Could this cause indefinite blocking? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Channel leak] If an error occurs between receiving the channel at line 84 and closing it at line 99, the channel may never be closed, leading to goroutine leaks in the limiter. (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Channel close race] At line 99, close(ch) is called, but if another goroutine also tries to close the same channel (due to limiter bugs), this will panic with 'close of closed channel'. (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: ServeEncoded()] [Nil addr pointer] At line 109, addr.String() is called without checking if addr is nil. Could a caller pass nil causing a panic and node crash? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Serve()] [Nil service backend] At line 93-94, if s.services[req.Service] returns a serviceEntry with a nil backend field, calling service.backend.Handle() will panic. Is this scenario possible? (High)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Register()] [Unlimited service registration] There's no limit on the number of services that can be registered. Could an attacker register millions of services to exhaust memory and cause node crashes? (Medium)

[File: les/vflux/server/service.go] [Function: Register()] [Service overwrite attack] There's no check at line 70 to prevent overwriting an existing service with the same ID. Could a malicious actor register a service with an existing ID to hijack legitimate service requests? (High)
